Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 08:54PM Shari0707 wrote: Here is a letter that my mother wrote for everyone's an update for today's doctor appointments ; Hi everyone, Well today was the first milestone with Shari. She completed chemotherapy and we celebrated that. She also had all her imaging done - MRI, mammogram, and ultrasound. The results were very good. The tumor shrunk and is about half its size. Also the lymph nodes look better. Overall, the degree of background intensity (cancer cellular its in tumor) is minimal which is a significant difference from the prior one. Before, it was moderate to severe.The chemo did its job. Yah!!! Tuesday, we meet with another plastic surgeon up here. If all works out, Shari will have surgery at the end of March-- removal of the tumor, mastectomy, and dissection of the lymph nodes. Biopsy. Hopefully those will be good too. So for now a weekend of celebration. Again thanks for all the good thoughts and prayers. They are working and keep them coming. Love, Rita. (Mom) Would have loved for bigger response but doc says that that's not always likely in er/pr positive her2 negative cancers... And she say I had good response....will know for definite at surgery... What worries me a little also is that I have read(I know, bad )that MRI are not always as accurate for measurement of residual cancer withthissame tumor type in so some others. Say er negative and/or her 2 positive.... It's like when I get good news, I always let something push,e back down... Anybody hear that about mri's?

Posts.Title: January 2013 surgery JRMH Lbwagner69

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 08:21AM Shari0707 wrote: Chemo is meant to be systemic treatment... It is supposed to be effective for killing the camcer cells in your body... They would no recommend it so much if they didn't think it was effective.. Also as one doing neoadjuvant chemo.. It's not like they kept trying different chemos until they found the one that worked.. Thereis a standard set of chemo meds and if that doesn't start shrinking tumor, it can b assumed it isn't working,... However, mine did shrink and they never changed course of treatment... It's not really once they find the right chemo .. Usually it is and if it isn't they change the course... Chemo is a choice I suppose, but I want hay small percentage in my arsenal... My tumor was not that big but I am young and it is grade 3.... So it did have some aggressive characteristics.... Not as much as if it was triple negative or her2 positve.. But docs want to give me best shot at longest life possible..that's why I am getting chemo.. As to why I got i before surgery,. I am not sure...usually they give it to those who are node positive and we knew at least one was positive the week of diagnosis.. But also maybe to shrink it so,e if I chose to have lumpectomy so they could get clean margins.. I am opting for bilateral mastectomy anyway.... I think they feel they can assess tumors response to chemo if it is in the body rather than after.. Bc if t is not responding then they can change course of treatment.. I wold le to think this.. As I did research too. And I also read if it changes node postive to node negative its a really good sign towards prognosis.... Good luck
Posts.Title: What determines if chemo happens before or after surgery? PamelaKay gingit
